Author: greendestiny
Content: Mp3 players didnt have a lot of features when the iPod was launched, and I don't think a portable harddrive solution was particularly simple (engineering wise) at the time. The iPod won because it was portable and had a large capacity, mp3 players for many years were either one or the other even after the iPod shot to fame.

Author: brett
Content: I think you're on to something. nickb's comment about iCal had me thinking along the same lines.

Author: staunch
Content: When I do have enough time to do some work, but I know it will get cut short by a scheduled event, it causes an almost non-stop sense of anxiety in the back of my mind. It's seriously distracting and feels horrible.

Author: xzibitendo
Title: What should a striving non-programmer do?
Content: I have all of these ideas for a startup burning inside me, but with no real programming skills and no partner (yet) I feel trapped.  Is it worth my time to teach myself programming? Any advice would be great.

Author: tristian
Content:
If I'm just working alone: ToDoList by AbstractSpoon Software http://www.abstractspoon.com/

For small projects it's enough to manage all my tasks, including bugs.

Author: mhartl
Content: I second catnaps. I've written before on news.yc about the nap-success I've had. Certainly any company I run will have a quiet place where people can crash for 15 or 20 minutes in the afternoon. Of course, so far the only such company's world headquarters was located in my apartment, and that kind of feels like cheating...

Author: Alex3917
Content: I like it. I added it as a link in my Firefox bookmarks bar. Definitely needs to support multiple chains though. Instead of multiple tabs, I think it would be best just to have a column of color blocks with the name of the chain on the right hand side of the page. Then when you clicked on a color that chain would be displayed.

Author: mikesabat
Content:
I think a lot of the marketing has to do with the prodct and the interface. I think this is something that you build first and then take it to sources - ie - Paramount Movie Studio. Whenever a movie or TV DVD is released they let your website know.

The marketing: On their 24 page "Want us to remind you as soon as 24 season 3 is on DVD? Get a free reminder with ____.com. As you grow build it out so that any organization can customize for any product or event and then put it on their site.

Author: aswanson
Content: That other 40%, if shared equally between men and children, means that approximately 80% of the purchasing decisions are made by women. I am basing this on the chauvinist assumption that women pick out and buy the majority of clothes for the kids. If this article is correct, that 80% holds for a lot more than clothes: http://www.clickz.com/3363331

Author: pg
Content: In grad school I consulted for a company making CAD software for clothing designers.  They said that 60% of the clothing business is women's clothing, and the other 40% shared between men and children.

Author: rms
Content: Send him our way, I'd love to interact with a legend. Maybe he could set the record straight, I can't imagine that the WSJ got everything right.

Author: rms
Content:
Infogami (Aaron Swartz) merged with reddit and became reddit.

You can try emailing Aaron Swartz but I'm not sure if he is interested in maintaining infogami. http://www.aaronsw.com/weblog/interruptdriven

Author: pg
Content:
I don't have any specific expectations. Usually I just say "please let me know if got anything wrong, or missed anything important." If I'm writing about something I don't understand well enough, I ask domain experts. I always ask Hutch Fishman about startup funding, for example.

I take responses pretty seriously. I've killed whole essays friends thought were bad. Usually I just have to rewrite a sentence or two.

Title: The most bizarre episode in the history of the papacy

Author: aswanson
Title: Is anyone making something women want?
Content: Not being sexist, but they seem to -want- more than us, and walking into any shopping area seems to confirm that vendors know this.  My problem is that from a tech standpoint, it's hard to gauge what a viable need for them is.

Author: Zak
Content: This thought is only half-formed, but perhaps holding entire programs in one's head is the defining characteristic of a hacker (as opposed to a programmer, developer, software engineer or anything else people call someone who writes code).
